title: David's Census and Judgment
shortSummary: This chapter recounts King David's sin in ordering a census of Israel, which was incited by Satan and displeased God. As a result, God sends a plague, but through repentance and sacrifice, David intercedes for the people, and God relents, demonstrating His justice and mercy.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David in Israel

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who orders the census, acknowledges his sin, and intercedes for the people through repentance and sacrifice.

keyCharacters.name: Joab
keyCharacters.description: Commander of David's army who reluctantly carries out the census, expressing concern over the king's command.

keyCharacters.name: Gad
keyCharacters.description: David's prophet (seer) who delivers God's message and options for judgment to David.

keyCharacters.name: Ornan (Araunah) the Jebusite
keyCharacters.description: Owner of the threshing floor where David builds an altar to stop the plague; offers the site and offerings to David.

definitions.definition: The adversary or accuser who opposes God's people and incites David to sin in this chapter.
An official count of the population, which in this context was a sinful act of pride and reliance on military strength.
A flat area where grain is separated from chaff, often used as a place of sacrifice in the Old Testament.
A divine messenger who executes God's judgment but also responds to God's command to cease destruction.

outline.heading: David’s Sinful Census
outline.description: Satan incites David to number Israel, which David commands despite Joab's objections. The census is completed, but it displeases God because it reflects a lack of trust in Him.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment and David’s Repentance
outline.description: God sends a plague on Israel as punishment. David confesses his sin and pleads for mercy, asking God to spare the people and take the punishment upon himself.

outline.heading: God’s Offer of Judgment Options
outline.description: Through the prophet Gad, God offers David three choices of punishment. David chooses to fall into God's hands, trusting in His mercy rather than human enemies.

outline.heading: The Angel’s Intervention and David’s Altar
outline.description: As the angel of the LORD is about to destroy Jerusalem, God commands him to stop. David buys the threshing floor from Ornan and builds an altar, offering sacrifices that bring God’s favor and end the plague.

application: Trust in God’s provision and protection rather than relying on human strength or numbers.
Confess and repent quickly when confronted with sin, acknowledging personal responsibility before God.
Seek God’s mercy in times of judgment, trusting in His compassion rather than fearing human enemies.
Honor God with sincere offerings and obedience, understanding that true worship requires cost and reverence.

keyVerses.text: And Satan stood up against Israel, and provoked David to number Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the spiritual origin of David’s sin, reminding believers of the reality of spiritual opposition.

keyVerses.text: So the LORD sent pestilence upon Israel: and there fell of Israel seventy thousand men.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the severe consequences of sin and God’s righteous judgment upon the nation.

keyVerses.text: And David said unto Gad, I am in a great strait: let me fall now into the hand of the LORD; for very great are his mercies: but let me not fall into the hand of man.
keyVerses.significance: David’s trust in God’s mercy over human judgment exemplifies faith and humility in the face of discipline.

keyVerses.text: And David built there an altar unto the LORD, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings, and called upon the LORD; and he answered him from heaven by fire upon the altar of burnt offering.
keyVerses.significance: This verse demonstrates God’s acceptance of true repentance and worship, bringing restoration and peace.
